calls.tldr: September quarter revenue rose 8% to $102.5B and EPS reached $1.85, closing FY2025 with a record $416B in revenue. Apple guided December-quarter revenue growth of 10%-12% with gross margin of 47%-48% and an estimated $1.4B tariff cost impact.
bullets: Revenue was $102.5B (+8% YoY) and EPS was $1.85, a September quarter record.
Services hit a record $28.8B (+15%) while iPhone revenue reached $49B (+6%).
December quarter guide: revenue +10%-12%, iPhone double-digit growth, gross margin 47%-48% with ~$1.4B tariff cost impact.
themes: Pricing and cost pressure shaping margins
calls.search_blob: Apple Inc. AAPL FY2025Q4 2025-10-30 September quarter revenue rose 8% to $102.5B and EPS reached $1.85, closing FY2025 with a record $416B in revenue. Apple guided December-quarter revenue growth of 10%-12% with gross margin of 47%-48% and an estimated $1.4B tariff cost impact. Revenue was $102.5B (+8% YoY) and EPS was $1.85, a September quarter record. Services hit a record $28.8B (+15%) while iPhone revenue reached $49B (+6%). December quarter guide: revenue +10%-12%, iPhone double-digit growth, gross margin 47%-48% with ~$1.4B tariff cost impact. Enterprise device refresh cycle evolving Services and software attach expanding Supply chain diversification improving resilience Pricing and cost pressure shaping margins AI-driven infrastructure demand scaling iPhone Revenue was $49B, up 6% YoY with strong demand for iPhone 17 family. Supply constraints limited availability on several models. Mac and iPad Mac revenue was $8.7B, up 13% YoY on MacBook Air strength. iPad revenue was $7B, flat YoY with a difficult compare. Services Revenue hit a record $28.8B, up 15% YoY with broad category growth. Fiscal year services revenue surpassed $100B, up 14%. Tariffs September quarter tariff costs were about $1.1B, in line with prior estimate. December quarter tariff costs projected at about $1.4B under current assumptions. Capital return Returned $24B to shareholders in Q4, including $20B in buybacks. Declared $0.26 dividend payable Nov 13, 2025. iPhone demand and China Management cited strong reception for iPhone 17 in China and expects return to growth. Supply constraints limited September quarter iPhone sales. Services acceleration Services growth was broad-based and organic, with double-digit growth across markets. No unusual one-time impacts were cited. Why was Greater China down in Q4? Supply constraints on iPhone models were the primary driver. What is driving December revenue acceleration? Strong iPhone 17 demand and holiday lineup strength support 10%-12% growth. How are tariff costs evolving? Tariff costs are expected to rise with volume, from $1.1B to $1.4B. Services growth and product mix support elevated gross margins into FY2026. Holiday demand and iPhone 17 cycle position Apple for its strongest December quarter. China demand recovery depends on supply normalization and subsidy impact. Track iPhone supply constraints through December quarter. Monitor tariff cost sensitivity as volumes rise. Validate iPhone 17 supply normalization in December. Track services growth durability after strong Q4 acceleration. How quickly can China return to sustained growth? Magnitude of AI-driven OpEx growth in FY2026. December quarter revenue growth versus 10%-12% guide. Gross margin performance with higher tariff costs.

calls.tldr: Q3 2025 revenue surged 15.4% QoQ to KRW 86.1T with operating profit of KRW 12.2T as memory sales hit a record and foundry utilization improved. Samsung guided mixed Q4 conditions, outlined a lower 2025 CapEx plan, and emphasized continued AI-led growth into 2026.
bullets: Revenue rose 15.4% QoQ to KRW 86.1T and operating profit jumped to KRW 12.2T for a 14.1% margin.
DS sales grew 19% QoQ with record memory revenue from HBM3E and server SSDs; DX revenue rose 11% on foldables.
Q3 CapEx was KRW 9.2T; full-year 2025 CapEx is projected at KRW 47.4T with dividend raised to KRW 370 per share.
themes: Pricing and cost pressure shaping margins
Industrial and logistics demand uneven by region
calls.search_blob: Samsung Electronics 005930.KS FY2025Q3 2025-10-29 Q3 2025 revenue surged 15.4% QoQ to KRW 86.1T with operating profit of KRW 12.2T as memory sales hit a record and foundry utilization improved. DS sales grew 19% QoQ with record memory revenue from HBM3E and server SSDs; DX revenue rose 11% on foldables. Q3 CapEx was KRW 9.2T; full-year 2025 CapEx is projected at KRW 47.4T with dividend raised to KRW 370 per share. AI-driven infrastructure demand scaling Capex discipline influencing capacity Pricing and cost pressure shaping margins Supply chain diversification improving resilience Industrial and logistics demand uneven by region Device Solutions (DS) Sales increased 19% QoQ with record memory revenue led by HBM3E and server SSDs. Foundry profitability improved on higher utilization and reduced one-off costs. Device eXperience (DX) Revenue increased 11% QoQ on foldable launches and solid flagship sales. MX expects premium-led growth but faces rising component costs in Q4. Shareholder returns Quarterly dividend of KRW 370 per share; KRW 2.45T payout due late November. KRW 10T buyback program completed by Sep 29; remaining cancellations to be decided. Memory roadmap HBM3E demand outpaced supply; HBM4 samples shipped with 11 Gbps-plus performance. Management expects AI server demand to remain strong into 2026. HBM competitiveness HBM3E shipments rose mid-80% QoQ; mix fully transitioned to HBM3E. HBM4 samples shipped; capacity expansion under review. Foundry recovery Losses narrowed on better utilization and fewer write-downs. 2nm GAA mass production started with expanding advanced node backlog. What is the memory outlook for 2026? Management expects AI-driven demand to exceed supply, supporting higher HBM and server DRAM volumes. How did foundry profitability improve in Q3? Reduced one-off costs and higher advanced-node utilization drove better results. Can MX sustain margins with rising component costs? Samsung plans to lean on flagship mix, ecosystem products, and process optimization. Record memory performance reinforces Samsung's leverage to AI server demand cycles. CapEx cuts signal discipline while protecting advanced node transitions. TV competition remains price-led, pushing Samsung to emphasize premium differentiation. Track HBM4 commercialization timelines and capacity expansion decisions. Monitor Q4 DS margin sustainability as HBM pricing volatility persists. Validate HBM3E pricing trends versus conventional DRAM margin convergence. Watch Q4 foundry utilization and 2nm ramp progress. Timing for cancellation of remaining repurchased shares. Degree of tariff impact on DX demand in Q4. Q4 memory pricing trajectory for DRAM and NAND. CapEx revisions if AI demand accelerates in 2026.

calls.tldr: Q3 2025 beat outlook with sales of $1.3B (+5%) and non-GAAP EPS of $3.88, led by retail, e-commerce, and RFID strength. Management guided Q4 sales growth of 8% to 11% with EPS of $4.20 to $4.40 and highlighted tariff mitigation progress and a $500M buyback.
bullets: Sales grew 5% to $1.3B with adjusted EBITDA margin of 21.6% and EPS up 11% to $3.88.
Asset Intelligence and Tracking grew 11% (RFID and printing led) while EVM grew 2% on strong mobile computing and softer scanning.
Q4 guide calls for 8% to 11% sales growth and EPS of $4.20 to $4.40; full-year EPS guided to about $15.80.
themes: Asset visibility and data capture adoption expanding
Pricing and cost pressure shaping margins
Portfolio shifts and M&A reshaping focus
calls.search_blob: Zebra Technologies ZBRA FY2025Q3 2025-10-28 Q3 2025 beat outlook with sales of $1.3B (+5%) and non-GAAP EPS of $3.88, led by retail, e-commerce, and RFID strength. Management guided Q4 sales growth of 8% to 11% with EPS of $4.20 to $4.40 and highlighted tariff mitigation progress and a $500M buyback. Sales grew 5% to $1.3B with adjusted EBITDA margin of 21.6% and EPS up 11% to $3.88. Asset Intelligence and Tracking grew 11% (RFID and printing led) while EVM grew 2% on strong mobile computing and softer scanning. Q4 guide calls for 8% to 11% sales growth and EPS of $4.20 to $4.40; full-year EPS guided to about $15.80. Enterprise device refresh cycle evolving Automation and workflow digitization accelerating Asset visibility and data capture adoption expanding Pricing and cost pressure shaping margins Portfolio shifts and M&A reshaping focus Enterprise Visibility and Mobility (EVM) Segment sales grew 2% with strong mobile computing and tougher compares in scanning. Management sees longer-term upside from AI-enabled devices and wearables. Asset Intelligence and Tracking (AIT) Segment sales grew 11% led by RFID and printing. RFID adoption continues to expand across retail, e-commerce, and logistics workflows. Regional performance North America grew 6% with strength in mobile computing and RFID; Canada was softer. Asia Pacific grew 23% led by Australia, New Zealand, India, and Japan initiatives. Latin America grew 8% on broad-based demand; EMEA declined 3% with weakness in Germany. Tariffs and pricing Expected 2025 gross profit impact reduced to about $24M after mitigation. Pricing actions expected to deliver about $60M annual benefit and roughly 1% sales growth. Capital allocation Planned $500M share repurchases over the next 12 months. Year-to-date buybacks exceeded $300M alongside Photoneo and Elo acquisitions. Demand and outlook Q3 demand was solid with some orders pulled forward; Q4 guide assumes similar year-end spend to last year. Management cited uneven demand in EMEA and Canada with manufacturing still soft. AI and refresh cycle AI opportunity seen in next-gen handhelds and wearables, driving a multi-year refresh cycle. Early pilots for AI Companion show productivity and sales conversion benefits. Why does Q4 guidance imply decelerating organic growth? Management said H2 demand matches prior expectations with some Q3 pull-forward and tougher comps. How should investors think about 2026 demand and long-term targets? Visibility is limited, but uneven demand persists while long-term growth drivers remain intact. How will the $500M buyback be deployed? Plan is to execute steadily over four quarters with flexibility to use market volatility. RFID expansion and frontline AI pilots indicate continued attach opportunities beyond core hardware. Elo integration expands the connected frontline TAM and should improve cross-sell into retail and hospitality. Pricing actions track broader industry moves in response to tariff impacts. Monitor Q4 conversion of pipeline assumed in the guide and incremental margin performance. Watch early benefits from Elo and Photoneo acquisitions on growth and EPS. Track Q4 demand in EMEA and Canada for signs of stabilization. Validate RFID growth drivers with retail and logistics channel checks. How quickly will AI Companion pilots convert into material software revenue? What is the sustainable baseline for China exposure once supply chain changes mature? Early visibility into new segment reporting (Connected Frontline and Asset Visibility and Automation). Update on tariff mitigation and pricing realization into 2026.

calls.tldr: Q3 2025 organic sales accelerated to 6% with adjusted EPS of $2.82, and orders jumped 22% to $11.9B with a book-to-bill above 1. Management raised full-year guidance again despite the Solstice spin impact, projecting sales of $40.7B-$40.9B and EPS of $10.6-$10.7, with Q4 sales of $10.1B-$10.3B and EPS of $2.52-$2.62.
bullets: Organic sales rose 6% and adjusted EPS increased 9% to $2.82; orders grew 22% to $11.9B and backlog hit another record.
Aerospace grew 12% organically (margin 26.1%); industrial automation returned to growth (+1%); building automation grew 7% with margin expansion; ESS declined 2% on licensing and catalyst timing.
Guidance raised: FY organic sales growth ~6% (5% ex-Bombardier), sales $40.7B-$40.9B, EPS $10.6-$10.7; Q4 EPS $2.52-$2.62 with segment margin 22.5% to 22.8%.
themes: Asset visibility and data capture adoption expanding
Pricing and cost pressure shaping margins
Industrial and logistics demand uneven by region

Solstice separation clarifies capital allocation and could improve margins in the remaining portfolio. Aerospace aftermarket and defense strength continues to outpace peers with slower OE recovery. Track Q4 ESS licensing and catalyst shipment timing versus the lower guide. Watch IA mix and margin trajectory as warehouse automation order timing normalizes. Check channel signals on aerospace OE inventory drawdown and delivery cadence. Validate ESS project timing and catalyst order pipelines for 2026. calls.tldr: Q2 2025 beat outlook with ~$1.3B sales (+6%), non-GAAP EPS of $3.61, and modest margin expansion despite tariffs. Management announced the pending $1.3B Elo Touch Solutions acquisition and raised full-year sales, EBITDA margin, EPS, and free cash flow guidance.
bullets: Sales rose about 6% to $1.3B with adj. EBITDA margin of 20.6% and non-GAAP EPS of $3.61 (+14% YoY).

Announced $1.3B acquisition of Elo Touch Solutions, expected to be immediately accretive.

Validate Elo cross-sell opportunities in retail, hospitality, and healthcare channels. Track RFID demand and transportation logistics momentum into Q3. calls.tldr: June quarter revenue rose 10% to $94B and EPS increased 12% to $1.57 as iPhone, Mac, and services all grew double digits. Apple guided September-quarter revenue to mid-to-high single-digit growth with gross margin of 46%-47% and tariff cost impact of about $1.1B.
bullets: Revenue was $94B (+10% YoY) with EPS of $1.57 (+12% YoY); services reached a record $27.4B (+13%).
iPhone revenue grew 13% to $44.6B; Mac revenue rose 15% to $8.0B; iPad revenue was $6.6B.
September quarter outlook: revenue mid-to-high single digits, gross margin 46%-47% including ~$1.1B tariff cost impact.
themes: Pricing and cost pressure shaping margins
calls.search_blob: Apple Inc. AAPL FY2025Q3 2025-07-31 June quarter revenue rose 10% to $94B and EPS increased 12% to $1.57 as iPhone, Mac, and services all grew double digits. Apple guided September-quarter revenue to mid-to-high single-digit growth with gross margin of 46%-47% and tariff cost impact of about $1.1B. Revenue was $94B (+10% YoY) with EPS of $1.57 (+12% YoY); services reached a record $27.4B (+13%). iPhone revenue grew 13% to $44.6B; Mac revenue rose 15% to $8.0B; iPad revenue was $6.6B. September quarter outlook: revenue mid-to-high single digits, gross margin 46%-47% including ~$1.1B tariff cost impact. Enterprise device refresh cycle evolving Services and software attach expanding Supply chain diversification improving resilience Pricing and cost pressure shaping margins AI-driven infrastructure demand scaling iPhone Revenue was $44.6B, up 13% YoY with record June-quarter upgraders. iPhone 16 family performance drove growth across all regions. Mac and iPad Mac revenue rose 15% to $8.0B on M4 MacBook Air strength. iPad revenue was $6.6B with a difficult compare versus prior-year launches. Services Revenue hit a record $27.4B, up 13% YoY with broad-based category acceleration. App Store revenue grew double digits and cloud services hit an all-time record. Tariffs June quarter tariff costs were about $800M. September quarter tariff costs estimated at about $1.1B under current policy assumptions. Capital return Returned over $27B to shareholders, including $21B in buybacks. Declared $0.26 dividend payable Aug 14, 2025. AI investment and CapEx CapEx is rising on AI investments and Private Cloud Compute capacity. Hybrid model uses both first-party and third-party data centers. Tariff pull-ahead Management estimated about 1 point of Q3 growth from pull-ahead demand. Pull-ahead was mainly in iPhone and Mac and mostly in the U.S. What drove the strong June quarter iPhone performance? Record upgraders and strong iPhone 16 family demand across regions. How is Apple managing tariff exposure? Supply chain optimization and sourcing shifts; outlook assumes current tariff rates hold. Is services strength impacted by the Epic ruling? Management said services growth was broad-based; changes were implemented late in the quarter. Services momentum supports margin stability despite tariff costs. AI investment ramp is becoming a larger driver of CapEx. Supply chain diversification toward India and Vietnam continues for U.S. sales. Track September quarter tariff costs versus $1.1B estimate. Monitor services growth rate relative to June-quarter pace. Validate upgrade rates and switcher mix for iPhone 16 family. Watch CapEx trend as AI investments expand. Magnitude of tariff headwinds if policies change post-September. Timing of more personalized Siri features. September quarter revenue growth versus mid-to-high single digit guide. Gross margin performance with tariff cost impact.

calls.tldr: Q2 2025 revenue fell 5.8% QoQ to KRW 74.6T and operating profit declined to KRW 4.7T as DX launch effects faded and DS absorbed inventory adjustments. Management expects a 2H rebound on AI memory demand, reiterated shareholder returns, and detailed HBM3E ramp and foundry order momentum.
bullets: Revenue decreased 5.8% QoQ to KRW 74.6T with operating profit of KRW 4.7T and a 6.3% margin.
DS sales rose 11% QoQ on HBM3E and DDR5, while DX revenue fell 16% after smartphone launch effects.
CapEx was KRW 11.1T (DS KRW 9.8T, display KRW 0.8T) and the KRW 10T buyback is set to complete by October.
themes: Pricing and cost pressure shaping margins
Industrial and logistics demand uneven by region

Preemptive purchasing may pull forward demand, but Samsung plans flexible mix management to protect profitability. Will foundry losses narrow in 2H? Management expects higher utilization and advanced node ramps to improve profitability. Inventory adjustments reset DS earnings but set a cleaner base for 2H rebound. Foundry order momentum (Tesla) improves credibility in advanced nodes. DX faces intensified TV competition while premium AI devices remain the margin lever. Track HBM3E mix and HBM4 qualification milestones. Monitor DS utilization recovery and foundry margin progression. Verify HBM3E pricing and mix impact in Q3 results. Track Taylor Fab ramp timeline and 2026 CapEx signals. How much pull-forward demand from tariffs reverses in 2H? Timing for cancellation of remaining buyback shares. Q3 earnings rebound versus Q2 bottoming guidance. Memory inventory normalization pace.

calls.tldr: March quarter revenue was $95.4B (+5%) with EPS of $1.65 as services hit a record and iPhone returned to growth. Apple guided June-quarter revenue to low-to-mid single digits and gross margin to 45.5%-46.5%, including an estimated $900M tariff cost impact.
bullets: Revenue was $95.4B (+5% YoY) and EPS was $1.65 (+8% YoY) with services up 12% to $26.6B.
iPhone revenue rose 2% to $46.8B; iPad was up 15% while wearables were down 5%.
June quarter outlook: revenue low-to-mid single digits, gross margin 45.5%-46.5% with ~$900M tariff cost impact.
themes: Pricing and cost pressure shaping margins
calls.search_blob: Apple Inc. AAPL FY2025Q2 2025-05-01 March quarter revenue was $95.4B (+5%) with EPS of $1.65 as services hit a record and iPhone returned to growth. Apple guided June-quarter revenue to low-to-mid single digits and gross margin to 45.5%-46.5%, including an estimated $900M tariff cost impact. Revenue was $95.4B (+5% YoY) and EPS was $1.65 (+8% YoY) with services up 12% to $26.6B. iPhone revenue rose 2% to $46.8B; iPad was up 15% while wearables were down 5%. June quarter outlook: revenue low-to-mid single digits, gross margin 45.5%-46.5% with ~$900M tariff cost impact. Enterprise device refresh cycle evolving Services and software attach expanding Supply chain diversification improving resilience Pricing and cost pressure shaping margins AI-driven infrastructure demand scaling iPhone Revenue was $46.8B, up 2% YoY on iPhone 16 family demand. iPhone install base and upgraders grew to all-time highs. Mac and iPad Mac revenue grew 7% to $7.9B with M4 MacBook Air and Mac Studio updates. iPad revenue grew 15% to $6.4B on new M3 iPad Air. Services Revenue hit a record $26.6B, up 12% YoY with broad-based growth. Services gross margin was 75.7% on favorable mix. Tariffs and supply chain Estimated $900M cost impact for June quarter under current tariff assumptions. Majority of U.S. iPhones expected to be sourced from India in June quarter. Capital return Authorized additional $100B in share repurchases and raised dividend 4% to $0.26. Returned $29B to shareholders in the quarter. Tariff mitigation Apple plans continued supply chain optimization and inventory build-ahead where feasible. Pricing changes were not announced. Apple Intelligence impact Markets with Apple Intelligence rollout showed stronger iPhone performance. Personalized Siri features require more time to meet quality standards. How large could tariff impacts be beyond June? Management said it is difficult to project beyond June due to policy uncertainty. Is there evidence of demand pull-forward? Apple saw no obvious evidence of a significant pull-forward in March quarter demand. What drove product gross margin decline? Mix, seasonality, FX, and loss of leverage were the key drivers. Tariff exposure is manageable near-term but could pressure margins if policies shift. India manufacturing expansion reduces U.S. tariff exposure over time. Services strength offsets hardware seasonality and FX headwinds. Track June quarter tariff cost versus the $900M estimate. Monitor Apple Intelligence language expansion effects on iPhone demand. Validate India-sourced iPhone mix for U.S. shipments. Watch for pricing actions if tariffs rise further. Timing for personalized Siri release beyond 2025. Extent of EU DMA impact on services growth. June quarter revenue growth versus low-to-mid single digit guide. Gross margin impact from tariff cost exposure.

calls.tldr: Q1 2025 revenue rose 4% QoQ to KRW 79.14T with operating profit of KRW 6.7T as DX strength offset weaker DS results from HBM softness. Management kept a cautious outlook for 2H recovery, increased shareholder returns, and highlighted AI, robotics, and advanced node investment priorities.
bullets: Revenue increased 4% QoQ to KRW 79.14T and operating profit rose to KRW 6.7T with an 8.4% margin.
DX revenue climbed 28% on flagship smartphones and high-end appliances, while DS revenue fell 17% due to deferred HBM demand.
CapEx was KRW 12.0T (DS KRW 10.9T, display KRW 0.5T) and the board declared a KRW 365 dividend with KRW 10T buyback in progress.
themes: Pricing and cost pressure shaping margins
Industrial and logistics demand uneven by region

AI-driven infrastructure demand scaling Capex discipline influencing capacity Pricing and cost pressure shaping margins Supply chain diversification improving resilience Industrial and logistics demand uneven by region Device Solutions (DS) Revenue declined 17% QoQ due to lower HBM sales and deferred AI demand. Memory focused on servers and high-density products while managing profitability. Device eXperience (DX) Revenue rose 28% QoQ driven by Galaxy S25 series and high-value home appliances. Visual Display and Digital Appliances contributed to operating profit growth. Shareholder returns Quarterly dividend of KRW 365 per share; Q1 payout of KRW 2.45T scheduled late May. KRW 10T buyback plan underway with KRW 3T remaining in progress. R&D and sustainability R&D spending rose 15% YoY to a record Q1 level. Company ranked first in a global supply chain human rights assessment. Tariffs and supply chain Management highlighted scenario planning and flexible global production to manage tariff volatility. Flagship products are exempt from current reciprocal tariffs, with investigations ongoing. HBM recovery HBM3E samples were shipped and gradual recovery is expected from Q2. HBM4 development remains on track with 2H mass production plans. How will Samsung address tariff uncertainty? The company plans to flex global production and focus on premium products to offset cost impacts. When does HBM demand recover? HBM sales are expected to improve sequentially as HBM3E ramps and new GPU launches resume demand. What drove MX profitability gains? Higher flagship mix, cost optimization, and lower component prices supported margins. HBM pause creates a near-term DS headwind but sets up a rebound with HBM3E/4 ramps. DX premium mix and AI features protect margins amid macro uncertainty. Foundry aims to improve profitability by expanding orders across advanced and mature nodes. Monitor HBM3E contribution starting Q2 and HBM4 timelines. Track foldable and flagship mix as tariff pressure builds. Validate HBM3E qualification progress with major GPU customers. Track CapEx pacing versus DS demand signals. Timing for full HBM demand normalization after export control impacts. Extent of tariff-related component cost increases for MX. Q2 DS rebound and HBM sales recovery. DX margin durability as launch effects fade.

calls.tldr: Q1 2025 beat guidance with 4% organic sales growth, flat segment margin at 23%, and adjusted EPS of $2.51. Management maintained full-year organic sales guidance at 2% to 5% while raising EPS outlook to $10.20 to $10.50 amid tariff uncertainty, and highlighted separation planning, the Sundyne deal, and significant buybacks.
bullets: Organic sales rose 4% with adjusted EPS up 7% to $2.51; orders were $10.6B and backlog hit a record $36.1B.
Aerospace grew 9% organically (commercial aftermarket +15%) and building automation grew 8%, while industrial automation and ESS declined 2% each.
Full-year guide: organic sales growth 2% to 5% (1% to 4% ex-Bombardier), sales $39.6B-$40.5B, EPS $10.20-$10.50; Q2 EPS $2.60-$2.70 on $9.8B-$10.1B sales.
themes: Asset visibility and data capture adoption expanding
Pricing and cost pressure shaping margins
Industrial and logistics demand uneven by region
calls.search_blob: Honeywell International HON FY2025Q1 2025-04-29 Q1 2025 beat guidance with 4% organic sales growth, flat segment margin at 23%, and adjusted EPS of $2.51. Management maintained full-year organic sales guidance at 2% to 5% while raising EPS outlook to $10.20 to $10.50 amid tariff uncertainty, and highlighted separation planning, the Sundyne deal, and significant buybacks. Organic sales rose 4% with adjusted EPS up 7% to $2.51; orders were $10.6B and backlog hit a record $36.1B. Aerospace grew 9% organically (commercial aftermarket +15%) and building automation grew 8%, while industrial automation and ESS declined 2% each. Full-year guide: organic sales growth 2% to 5% (1% to 4% ex-Bombardier), sales $39.6B-$40.5B, EPS $10.20-$10.50; Q2 EPS $2.60-$2.70 on $9.8B-$10.1B sales. Automation and workflow digitization accelerating Asset visibility and data capture adoption expanding Pricing and cost pressure shaping margins Industrial and logistics demand uneven by region Capex discipline influencing capacity Aerospace Technologies Organic sales rose 9% with commercial aftermarket up 15% and defense and space delivering another double-digit quarter. Segment margin declined to 26.3% on mix and CASE integration headwinds, partially offset by productivity. Industrial Automation Organic sales declined 2% with PPE weakness and softer Europe/China, while warehouse and workflow solutions returned to growth (+5%). Segment margin fell 130 bps to 17.8% on volume deleverage and receivables write-downs. Building Automation Organic sales grew 8% with double-digit growth in building solutions and strength in fire and security products. Segment margin expanded 150 bps on volume leverage, productivity, and access solutions accretion. Energy and Sustainability Solutions Organic sales declined 2%; EOP grew 2% while advanced materials fell 4% on tough flooring comps. Segment margin expanded 230 bps on LNG acquisition benefits and productivity. Tariffs and mitigation Guide assumes current tariffs net of mitigation actions and a demand contingency of roughly 1% on organic sales. Local-for-local footprint and operating system actions are expected to offset tariff impacts. Portfolio actions and capital return Announced Sundyne acquisition; PPE exit expected in early May. Repurchased $3B of stock year to date and reaffirmed opportunistic buybacks. Tariffs and demand assumptions Management said tariff impacts are embedded in guidance with mitigation actions underway. Demand uncertainty is concentrated in short-cycle IA and some energy projects. Aerospace mix and margin OE revenue softness was attributed to mix and revenue recognition timing, not volume. Aero margins are expected to remain around the Q1 run rate for 2025. How much demand destruction is embedded in the 2025 guide? Management cited about a 1% organic sales impact with roughly $0.18 EPS headwind versus the February outlook. Why did aero OE revenue lag while volumes improved? Mix of cost-over-sale products and revenue timing drove the shortfall; volumes were up and management expects improvement later in the year. What is the timing for the planned separations? Advanced materials is targeted for late 2025/early 2026, with aerospace timing to be refined as regulatory steps progress. Local-for-local manufacturing reduces tariff exposure versus more globally exposed peers. Portfolio moves (Sundyne and PPE exit) continue to tilt Honeywell toward higher-margin, long-cycle end markets. Pricing actions and productivity offsets suggest limited near-term share pressure despite tariff volatility. Monitor aero OE revenue recoupling with build rates and CASE integration cost timing. Track IA margin improvement as PPE exits and tariff mitigation actions ramp. Validate IA demand trends in China and Europe with channel checks. Confirm building automation backlog conversion pace in North America and the Middle East. How quickly will Sundyne close and contribute to 2025 results? Will tariff mitigation fully offset the $0.18 EPS headwind assumed in guidance? Q2 margin performance versus the 22.8% to 23.2% guide range. Updates on separation timeline and stranded cost planning.

calls.tldr: Q1 2025 beat outlook with over $1.3B in sales (+12%), record gross margin, and non-GAAP EPS of $4.20. Demand stayed solid into Q2, but higher tariff costs pushed down full-year margin and EPS guidance.
bullets: Sales grew 12% to over $1.3B with adjusted EBITDA margin of 22.3% and non-GAAP EPS of $4.20 (+42% YoY).
Asset Intelligence and Tracking grew 18% and EVM grew 9%; all regions posted growth led by EMEA and Latin America.
Tariff outlook worsened: full-year gross profit impact now about $70M after mitigation; Q2 guide calls for ~4% to 7% sales growth.
themes: Asset visibility and data capture adoption expanding

Portfolio shifts and M&A reshaping focus

calls.tldr: Q4 FY2025 revenue increased 7% to $23.9B with EPS up 18% to $2.68, driven by strong ISG margins and storage mix. Dell posted FY2025 revenue of $95.6B and EPS of $8.14, and guided FY2026 revenue of $101B-$105B with EPS of $9.3 +/- $0.25 on $15B of AI server shipments.
bullets: Q4 revenue rose 7% to $23.9B with EPS up 18% to $2.68; ISG margin hit a record 18.1%.
AI orders were $1.7B and shipments were $2.1B, with $4.1B backlog; AI backlog reached about $9B as of February.
FY2026 guide: revenue $101B-$105B, EPS $9.3 +/- $0.25, ISG high-teens growth on $15B of AI shipments.
themes: Pricing and cost pressure shaping margins

calls.tldr: Q1 FY2025 revenue rose 6% to $22.2B with AI server momentum and a return to commercial PC growth, but margins compressed on AI mix and pricing. Management guided FY2025 revenue of $93.5B-$97.5B and EPS of $7.65 +/- $0.25, expecting ISG growth above 20% and CSG low-single-digit growth.
bullets: Revenue grew 6% to $22.2B and diluted EPS was $1.27; ISG revenue rose 22% while CSG was flat.
AI server orders were $2.6B with $1.7B of shipments; AI pipeline remained multiple of backlog.
themes: Pricing and cost pressure shaping margins
calls.search_blob: Dell Technologies DELL FY2025Q1 2024-05-30 Q1 FY2025 revenue rose 6% to $22.2B with AI server momentum and a return to commercial PC growth, but margins compressed on AI mix and pricing. Management guided FY2025 revenue of $93.5B-$97.5B and EPS of $7.65 +/- $0.25, expecting ISG growth above 20% and CSG low-single-digit growth. Revenue grew 6% to $22.2B and diluted EPS was $1.27; ISG revenue rose 22% while CSG was flat. AI server orders were $2.6B with $1.7B of shipments; AI pipeline remained multiple of backlog. FY2025 guide: revenue $93.5B-$97.5B, EPS $7.65 +/- $0.25; Q2 revenue $23.5B-$24.5B and EPS $1.65 +/- $0.10. Enterprise device refresh cycle evolving AI-driven infrastructure demand scaling Services and software attach expanding Pricing and cost pressure shaping margins Supply chain diversification improving resilience Infrastructure Solutions Group (ISG) Revenue grew 22% to $9.2B; server and networking revenue rose 42% to a record $5.5B. Storage revenue was flat at $3.8B with strength in HCI, PowerMax, PowerStore, and PowerScale. Operating income was $736M (8% margin), down slightly with seasonally lower storage profitability. Client Solutions Group (CSG) Revenue was flat at $12.0B; commercial revenue grew 3% to $10.2B while consumer declined 15%. Operating income was $732M (6.1% margin) as pricing remained competitive. AI servers and pipeline AI server orders were $2.6B with $1.7B shipments; pipeline expanded again and remained a multiple of backlog. Management highlighted AI attach opportunities in storage, networking, and services. Capital return Repurchased 6.7M shares at $108.38 and paid a $0.45 dividend. Returned $8B since FY2023 inception, or 103% of adjusted free cash flow. Margin drivers AI server mix and competitive pricing pressured gross margin rates. ISG margins expected to improve with storage seasonality and mix. AI backlog and lead times Lead times vary by GPU platform and customer allocation, with H100 availability improving and H200/B200 ramping. Backlog remains NVIDIA-heavy and pipeline continues to grow. AI margin profile AI servers are margin-rate dilutive but margin-dollar accretive. Storage seasonality and large-enterprise server mix also pressured margins. How should investors think about AI server lead times and backlog conversion? Lead times depend on GPU platform allocation; backlog builds as Dell secures parts and customer delivery slots. Are AI servers driving lower ISG margins? Mix and large-bid server profiles pressured Q1 margins; management expects ISG margins to improve through the year. What signals point to a PC refresh? Management cited an aging installed base, Windows 10 end-of-life, and AI PC capabilities as key catalysts. AI server mix pressure may persist until storage and services attach ramps. Enterprise AI pipeline growth supports multi-quarter ISG upside. Pricing remains competitive in PCs and large enterprise server bids. Track AI backlog conversion as H200 and B200 availability ramps. Watch storage revenue return to growth in the second half. Monitor PC refresh indicators through commercial pipeline activity. Validate AI server attach rates with storage and services partners. Check commercial PC pipeline trends against Windows 10 refresh timing. How quickly will AI pricing actions offset input cost inflation? When will storage growth turn positive and lift ISG margins? Q2 ISG margin progression and storage mix improvement. AI server shipments versus the $1.7B Q1 baseline.
